chunks.original_text: 名其灰为紫灰也。 名药正白，梼万杵，别器盛之。 色赤者不可用。 牝桂卒验者，梼 目视之有细坼，随复泥其坼，勿复坼也。 烧之以薪火，昼夜七日，发视色皆青者，可也。 未青者，复泥烧之七日，复寒之一日，发视未青，复烧如前，以色青为效也。 各异器盛之。 又取好名药纯白者，多少在意，梼之千杵，以云母水淹之令泥，泥尔正三物，各异器藏之。 欲用时，取流水中白石子，大如桃李者，打令中破甚细者，良。 用之一斗石子，以着煮器中，水淹之，令上有三四寸水。 取三药各重一方寸匕，投中搅之，猛火煮之，以物数数刺，视石子水尽，复益，熟则刺之入也，状如煮芋，可饱食取足，以当谷。 有葱盥豉及肉者，在意所加，益美耳。 张太玄将弟子二十余人，於陆浑山中，食此三十余年，皆肥丁。 天下太平，乃出。 无赤土釜者，赤缅赤瓶皆可用。 皆先斋戒二十一日，於密处起火，唯煮时不复污秽耳。 又法 直取五茄地榆根，阴乾，上釜中灰之如上法。 灰成，以三方寸匕，煮一斗石便熟，不须名药云母水也。 又煮石 常以七月七日，取地榆根，多少自在，阴乾百日，烧之为灰。 复取生者，与灰合梼万下，灰三分，梼生者末一分，合之。 欲为石二斗，若三斗渍石，水出石三寸，所用药粉水中搅之，然火煮之数沸，而烂如饵，可食取饱。 亦可与葱及盥豉煮如肉，所谓仙人石芋羹也。 真人服食饵石 取石大如鹦子，青白细泽如脂者，十枚，纳铜器中，渍汁一斗，纳地榆灰，大如鹦子者，炊一石米，顷成。 梼木玉大如鹅子，复煮之。 炊一石米，顷以箸刺之，熟如芋可食。 地榆根叶并烧作灰，用之木玉者，桂也。 或云筒母桂。 入山服石绝粮 取三色石，大如雀卵圆兜者，三七二十一枚。 欲服石时，先怀温，清旦吞青石七枚，日中吞赤石七枚，日暮吞白石七枚。 绝谷满十日，作葵子汤，姜去滓，服汁半升，须臾石即下矣。 挣洗石，后日复服。 先作碎米粥，清饮之二日，可食。 复洗故石服之，复绝食十五日，复作葵汤下之，如前复食粥清，可五日，复洗故石服之，可绝食百日。 复作葵汤下之，又服粥清，可食十日，复服故石，可绝一年。 一年之后，可至万日。 常洗故石服之，渴饮水，不食余物。 服石二年，日能行六百里，颜色转好，与神明通。 神仙举形 取石粉置寒水中，少顷水热如汤，可饮之。 如饮玉粉。 常服之可以轻举，涉水导山，可以去矣。 石粉所居者，气独上出。 ，天雨上乾，天燥上温，太一副世仙。 经日：石有玉白，或在山泽地气，必有美泉之源。 饮此泉水，皆通於神明。 神仙服食石锺乳 石锺乳，味甘，无毒，温。 一名孔公乳，主明目，下气益精。 故服食石锺乳，梼下筛，服之，恣口酒送，无酒水送之。 服百日，通神明。 久服，除百病，堪寒不饥。 服锺乳，当得其乳头，高二 寸，已下一寸，才触便折，为好。 其房曰：孔公孽，不如乳头也。 神仙服食饵赤石脂 赤石脂，味酸，无毒。 白石脂，味甘，无毒，平。 黑石脂，味咸，无毒，平。 黄石脂，味苦，无毒，平。 青石脂，味酸，无毒，平。 皆养性长年药也。 炼五石脂 梼末纳水中，研之令靡微净沙状，其泥石在下。 取其上者。 如此十五过，乾之。

The ash is named "purple ash." The medicine, when properly refined, is pure white; pound it ten thousand times and store it in a separate vessel. If the color is red, it cannot be used. For *pin gui* that proves effective upon testing, pound it while observing for fine cracks, then seal the cracks with mud to prevent further splitting. Burn it with firewood for seven days and nights; if upon inspection the color is entirely green, it is ready. If not yet green, reseal it with mud and burn for another seven days, then cool for one day. If upon inspection it remains ungreen, repeat the burning as before, taking the green color as the sign of success. Store each in separate vessels.

Take fine, pure-white *ming yao*, in whatever quantity desired, pound it a thousand times, and soak it in mica-infused water until it becomes muddy. Mix these three substances evenly, and store each in separate vessels. When ready to use, take white pebbles from flowing water, the size of peaches or plums, and strike them to break into very fine pieces. For one *dou* of pebbles, place them in a cooking vessel and cover with water, leaving three to four *cun* of water above. Take one *fangcun bi* of each of the three medicines, add them to the vessel, and stir. Boil vigorously, frequently piercing with an implement to check the pebbles; when the water is nearly gone, replenish it. When fully cooked, the pebbles will be easily pierced, resembling boiled taro. Eat to satiety as a substitute for grain. Onions, salted beans, or meat may be added as desired for enhanced flavor.

Master Zhang Taixuan, with over twenty disciples, consumed this in the Luhun Mountains for more than thirty years, all growing robust. They emerged only when the world was at peace. If no red-clay cauldrons are available, red-glazed jars or red bottles may be used. All must first purify themselves for twenty-one days, kindle the fire in a secluded place, and avoid defilement only during the cooking process.

Another method: simply take the roots of *wu qie di yu*, dry them in the shade, and burn them in a cauldron as described above. Once the ash is ready, use three *fangcun bi* to cook one *dou* of pebbles until done—no *ming yao* or mica-infused water is needed.

For cooking stones: on the seventh day of the seventh month, gather *di yu* roots in any quantity, dry them in the shade for a hundred days, and burn them to ash. Then take fresh roots, pound them together with the ash—three parts ash to one part fresh root—and combine. To prepare two or three *dou* of stones, soak them in water with three *cun* of water above, stir in the medicinal powder, and boil until bubbling. When tender like rice cakes, they may be eaten to satiety. They may also be cooked with onions and salted beans like meat—this is the "immortal’s stone-taro stew."

For the Realized One’s method of consuming stones: take stones the size of pigeon eggs, fine and lustrous like jade, ten in number, place them in a bronze vessel, and soak in one *dou* of juice. Add *di yu* ash the size of pigeon eggs, and cook with one *shi* of rice until done. Pound *mu yu* the size of goose eggs, then boil again. Cook with one *shi* of rice until done, piercing with chopsticks; when tender like taro, they may be eaten. The *di yu* roots and leaves are burned to ash for use with *mu yu*, which is cinnamon—or some call it *tong mu gui*.

To enter the mountains and consume stones while fasting: take three types of stones, round and the size of sparrow eggs, twenty-one in total. When ready to consume, first warm the body. At dawn, swallow seven green stones; at midday, seven red stones; at dusk, seven white stones. After ten days of fasting, prepare mallow-seed broth, strain out the dregs, and drink half a *sheng* of the liquid. Soon the stones will descend. Wash the stones, and consume them again the next day. First prepare a thin rice porridge and drink the clear liquid for two days before eating. Wash the used stones and consume them again, then fast for fifteen days. Prepare mallow broth to induce their descent as before, then drink the porridge’s clear liquid for five days. Wash the used stones and consume them again, fasting for a hundred days. Prepare mallow broth once more to induce their descent, then drink the porridge’s clear liquid for ten days. Consume the used stones again, and one may fast for a year. After a year, one may extend this to ten thousand days. Continuously wash and consume the used stones, quenching thirst with water and eating nothing else. After two years of consuming stones, one may walk six hundred *li* in a day, one’s complexion will improve, and one will commune with the divine.

To ascend as an immortal: place stone powder in cold water; after a short while, the water will grow hot as broth and may be drunk. Like drinking jade powder, regular consumption enables one to become weightless, traverse water and mountains, and depart. Where stone powder resides, its *qi* rises uniquely. When the sky rains, the area above remains dry; when the sky is arid, the area above remains warm—this is the celestial counterpart of worldly immortality.

The *Classic* states: "Stones with jade-like whiteness, found in the *qi* of mountains, marshes, or earth, must have a source of fine springs. Drinking this spring water all connects one to the divine."

For consuming stalactites: stalactites are sweet in flavor, non-toxic, and warming. Also called *kong gong ru*, they brighten the eyes, descend *qi*, and replenish essence. To consume, pound them, sift, and take freely, washing them down with wine or water if no wine is available. After a hundred days, one will commune with the divine. With prolonged consumption, all illnesses are dispelled, and one becomes resistant to cold and hunger. When consuming stalactites, one should obtain those with stalactite tips two *cun* in height; those less than one *cun* that break upon touch are superior. Their chambers are called *kong gong nie*, but these are inferior to the stalactite tips.

For consuming red halloysite: red halloysite is sour in flavor and non-toxic. White halloysite is sweet, non-toxic, and neutral. Black halloysite is salty, non-toxic, and neutral. Yellow halloysite is bitter, non-toxic, and neutral. Green halloysite is sour, non-toxic, and neutral. All are medicines for nourishing life and prolonging years.

To refine the five halloysites: pound them into powder, place in water, and grind until fine like sand, with the sediment settling below. Collect the upper portion. Repeat this process fifteen times, then dry.
